content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can write a function to clean column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    # Lowercase the string
    str = lowercase(col)
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespace
    str = strip(str)
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    str = replace(str, r"\s|-" => "_")
    return str
end
```

This function `clean_column` takes a string `col` as input and returns the cleaned version of the column name. It first lowercases the string, then strips any leading or trailing whitespace, and finally replaces spaces and hyphens with underscores.

You can use this function like so:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("my column  - with   spaces")
"my_column_with_spaces"
```

This function is designed to work on a single column name at a time. If you need to apply this function to multiple columns or an entire data frame, you would use it in conjunction with other Julia functions like `map` or `eachrow` depending on the structure of your data.
